race.name: Mid-State Gravel Grinder
race.tagline: Mid-State Gravel Grinder. 50 miles of gravel through Central Pennsylvania.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Pennsylvania countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Pennsylvania event. Rolling terrain with moderate access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Mid-State Gravel Grinder is a local event in Pennsylvania—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Pennsylvania countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Pennsylvania gravel race. Worth it for Pennsylvania/Northeast riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Pennsylvania—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Pennsylvania races: Dirty Kanza PA, Trans-Sylvania Epic.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Central PA has good lodging options.
logistics.food: Central PA has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Pennsylvania rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Starting at Mid-State Airport on Airport Road works fine — 7:00 AM registration, 8:30 AM close, 9:00 AM start keeps things moving. Aid stations at miles 16 and 26 for the half course with cutoff at noon. Lynn Botelho had her nutrition dialed in and the basic setup delivered what she needed.

length.explanation: The 48-mile half course hits that middle distance sweet spot — long enough for strategy but short enough for newcomers. Evan McGregor executed a patient race plan, staying with stronger riders until the decisive Tram Road descent. HoboStephen completed his first-ever bike race here after just four months of cycling. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: The baby head gravel descent spans 1-1.5 miles and demands respect — Lynn Botelho's race strategy was simply 'Stay Upright' rather than push speed. Multiple gates require dismounting, plus nearly U-turns and embedded rock on Tram Road where Evan McGregor took three minutes off his previous descent time. Less technical than The Mid South. As Evan McGregor puts it: "I took the lead on Tram into its climb and from there I pushed a high pace to discourage any attacking, but without going over the line. On the descents and corners, I went hard to keep a lead spot..."

elevation.explanation: At 3,458 feet over 48 miles, Lynn Botelho calls this 'relatively flat course for us in PA' — which tells you everything about Pennsylvania gravel standards. The climbing is consistent enough that Evan McGregor could use descending skills rather than raw power to create his winning 30+ second gap. Less climbing than The Mid South. As Evan McGregor puts it: "I took the lead on Tram into its climb and from there I pushed a high pace to discourage any attacking, but without going over the line. On the descents and corners, I went hard to keep a lead spot..."

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 82°F and lows of 64°F, with a 61% chance of rain on any given day. The August date shows in the DNF rates — the 70-mile course had 20.5% DNFs versus just 2.8% on the shorter distance. Heat and humidity take their toll on the longer efforts, though the 9:00 AM start helps beat the worst conditions. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Philipsburg sits around 1,500 feet — zero altitude considerations for anyone. The bumpy airfield finish brings you right back to where you started at Mid-State Airport. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Course maps show dirt/gravel roads in red, paved in black through central Pennsylvania farm country. The route includes several gates to wiggle through and almost U-turns that break up the standard gravel rhythm. It's honest miles through honest terrain without trying to be more than it is.

prestige.explanation: This is a regional PA gravel race that barely registers on the national radar. No notable pro riders, no prize purse, no YouTube coverage — just basic event listings on BikeReg and RaceRoster. They had to move the 2026 date to August 15th and start from an airport road address tells you everything about their draw power.

race_quality.explanation: The race exists and happens consistently, with 2025 and 2026 editions scheduled in Philipsburg. But zero course details, no aid station info, no cutoff times — this screams bare-bones operation. When your entire race description is 'continue gravel races around Pennsylvania,' you're not setting the bar high.

experience.explanation: Evan McGregor describes balancing 'my role as husband and father fitting more in balance with my competitive nature' during race weekend. The event accommodates both newcomers like HoboStephen calling it 'perfect' and elites executing tactical racing on technical descents.

community.explanation: It's a local PA gravel scene event that keeps the regional riders busy in August. Listed across multiple platforms suggests some established community support, but the complete absence of rider chatter online is telling. You'll find your people, but don't expect deep connections or lasting friendships. As Lynn Botelho puts it: "Even more happy to see and talk to so many other BaseCamp people. Most happy for being part of this great community and being able to keep learning and improving."

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 50-100 riders, no field size data, no notable past winners, no pro presence whatsoever. This is weekend warrior territory through and through. If you're looking to test yourself against serious competition, keep looking — this field won't challenge anyone beyond the local club level. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder. As Evan McGregor's winning strategy puts it: "My pre-race plan took hold. Stick in, help keep the pace relatively high, and when we get to Tram Road, go for it."

value.explanation: You get multiple distance options, proper aid stations, and technical challenges that can decide races on descending skills. Part of the Trans-Sylvania series for points chasers, beginner-friendly enough for first-timers, with course features that reward bike handling over just power.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-75. Airport start eliminates parking concerns, and central Pennsylvania keeps costs reasonable compared to destination events. One rider asked about 40mm tire clearance on their 2019 Crux, suggesting the terrain demands some equipment consideration but nothing exotic. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.
